video.title: Learn PostgreSQL Tutorial - Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn how to use PostgreSQL in this full course. PostgreSQL is a general purpose and object-relational database management system. It is the most advanced open source database system widely used to build back-end systems.

topLevelComment.author: Mercantilism
topLevelComment.text:
Note for beginners:

34:50
Here, he is using a command prompt, not postgres shell. If " psql - -help" does not work on your terminal, you need to add an environment variable. This video explains how to add one. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0EBkVzIBnoc

35:44
If your password does not work, use 'postgres' for the username.  Your code should look like this " psql -h localhost -p 5432 -U postgres test"
This is simply because you have not created a user account called 'user'

replies.author: Jennifer Dubois
replies.text: @Windows 99 In the Windows menu search environmental variables, it'll give you a window with a button that on it, go into there, highlight PATH, click edit, then click ADD to add paths at the end (this is so the command line/powershell can find it's way). Add the full directory path of Postgres (for ex. C:/This PC/Program Files/PostgreSQL15) and the one for the bin (for ex. C:/This PC/Program Files/PostgreSQL15/bin).  Hit all the OK's to get out, and psql should work in the terminal/powershell/command line by entering psql -U postgres and it should ask you for your password, and then it'll confirm your postgres version number and the windows-specific help commands.

topLevelComment.author: Ray Silva
topLevelComment.text: Also, in the Windows SQL shell (psql), it comes up in a tiny window. I can temporarily change the font so it will show in a readable window, but I get a dialog that says unable to modify the shortcut. It goes to a batch file. I don't know how to edit it, but trying to just use the psql.exe at the end of it does not work. It comes up asking for a password for my Windows user, but when I enter it, the window closes. It doesn't matter if I use the user main login password or the WSL sudo password, or the postgres database password. I'd think it would need the remote Railway database password and user credentials.

replies.author: Ray Silva
replies.text: I did a little more research and found that you can edit the runpsql.bat file in the scripts folder inside the bin folder. It's a bit tricky since you may have to do this from your Administrator account (not just your user account with Administrator privileges). Anyway, you just add the line cmd.exe /c chcp 1252 in the file before the SET commands. Then you click on that file to run it. It was already in the psql (shell) shortcut, but you need special permissions to modify it. That will be less complicated than taking ownership of the file as your regular user.

replies.author: Ray Silva
replies.text: OK, I figured out that you must not only set a path to the psql.exe command location, but also in Windows give the "trusted" command ./psql; but that's not all. It doesn't accept my user Windows login password or even the postgres password that I declared when installing. I had to add -d postgres and -U postgres, so the complete command was ./psql -d postgres -U postgres. Then I gave the postgres password and got into the command shell. One problem step out of the way. I'll add remote login when I figure that one out.

topLevelComment.author: Khateeb Anwer
topLevelComment.text:
For someone who is following this tutorial currently :

1) at around 01:06:00 when you go through the SQL file in VSCode , do change the value of varchar of gender greater than 20 because Mockaroo includes more than 2 genders in randomly generated database which will throw an error during its execution through cli when not changed.

2)When using terminal (for windows users ) , you might get errors during execution of sql file through cli due to path format which can easily be dealt with --> before even opening your postgres ,navigate through the command line where the actual file is located and then open postgres and use   \i filename.extension   to execute your file.

3)When installing postgres , always provide passwords without any alphanumeric characters like "$" otherwise it will throw an error during the installation phase ( I don't know what is that error as it was really vague but this worked for me).

topLevelComment.author: Brian Luman
topLevelComment.text: I tried taking this course but I was completely lost at 33:36. With some help from other youtube videos, the comments and searching online I was able to progress to 35:44 and ran into further issues. This is likely a great course but it is obvious that it isn't exactly for beginners as some prior knowledge is required to advance through these steps. Many people in the comments have had the same issues with no clear fix. I dug around on the internet quite a bit and found some patch work fixes but I still have no clear understanding of what is wrong or why my Terminal isn't the same as the instructors. A fair warning (this may just be for Windows users?) if you are a beginner this is likely not the course for you. I say this because when learning new skills it is worth while to get some minor successes before you start running into larger hurdles to get the momentum going. It seems to me that many people are unable to progress to the point of even accessing their database due to the inconsistencies in the instruction in this video. Basically I would look elsewhere and return to this video for further guidance once you actually get going.

Hey everyone. For windows users on the mockaroo section: I encountered some problems importing the .sql file. Apparently psql doesn't accept the common backslashes \ that are used for paths on windows. So you need to use forward slashes / like on linux or mac. So for example, here's what I typed in psql:

\i C:/Users/MyName/Desktop/person.sql

replies.author: Johan Huysman
replies.text:
@GabrielFrom another comment below ;)

 For Windows users it's even easier, even though it seems to be confusing, just enter database name when it ask for it. 

This how it looks in the shell:
-
Server [localhost]:

Database [postgres]: test

Port [5433]:

Username [postgres]:

Password for user postgres:your_pw
-
Please note when you connect for the first time you are actually connect to default one and that's why you don't enter any name, it will have name"postgres", and the owner is also default one, guess the name - "postgres".
-
When you login with all empty parameters you noted line in terminal like "postgres=#", well the part before "=#" is actually name of database, so in this default case "postgres".
-
You noted he has owner "amigoscode" (when he list all databases) , it's actually added role, check postgres documentation how to add role and change owner of table.
-
Also, when you are in "postgres=#" database you can easily switch to another (that is already created, it won't create it by itself) database using command: 
\c another_database_name 
(example: "postgres=# \c test"
 result: "test=#")

topLevelComment.author: Christian Hörauf
topLevelComment.text:
Hint about loading data from an SQL-file (1h 2m-1h-12m): Since the Video has been shot, Mockaroo seems to have changed their policy for representing gender. When I tried to import the sql file I ran into the error ERROR:  value too long for type character varying(7). This happens, because Mockaroo not only outputs Male and Female but also several other genders like 'Genderfluid', 'Non-binary', etc. To fix this change the size of the gender-colum to 25 in the CREATE TABLE command: 
create table person (
    id BIGSERIAL NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY,
    first_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    last_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    email VARCHAR(150),
    gender VARCHAR(25) NOT NULL,
    date_of_birth DATE NOT NULL,
    country_of_birth VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL
);

topLevelComment.author: Ananda Kumar Santhinathan
topLevelComment.text: AT 2:03:39, SELECT 10 / 2 gives a result of 5. If we are to try SELECT 10 / 4, it would give the answer as 2, and not 2.5. This is because of the way computers work. An integer divided by an integer will always yield an integer. On the other hand, if you are to type-in SELECT 10.0 / 4, then you would get the right answer 2.5, because in this case the numerator is not an integer any more and is a fractional decimal number. And so the answer given out is also a fractional decimal number.

topLevelComment.author: David Jiang
topLevelComment.text:
For windows users following this tutorial I had these problems: 
1. I couldn't connect to the database using the SQL Shell: 
I noticed I had a previous version of Postgres installed, and thus my admin account was set up incorrectly.
To fix it, uninstall all previous versions, then re-install the version that you want. 

2. I had trouble using the \i command from windows
I didn't know how to give the correct file path to the .sql file in SQL Shell. 
1. Add psql to your environment variable
2. In cmd, cd to the directory where the sql file is
3. Start psql by using: psql -U postgres
Then you can run the .sql file using \i correctly.

Hope this helps!

replies.author: Níkolas Schildberg
replies.text:
Hi there! That got me too when I started doing JOINs. Some identation and parenthesis may help you see the logic. Please try to interpret the code like this:

"""
SELECT
    column1, column2...
FROM
    (person JOIN car)
"""

Or even more complete:
"""
SELECT
    [column1, column2...]
FROM
(
    person JOIN car
       ( ON [ criteria ] )
)
"""

Looking at the syntax that way helped me to understand better.

It means sql first JOINs the two tables according to the specified criteria, and from the JOIN result sql then SELECTs what you want.

Hope that helps :)

replies.author: h3iberg
replies.text:
Short answer: you need to add a path to psql.exe folder in your environment variables.

It happens because when you enter 'psql' in command line, the file psql.exe doesn't exist in your current folder. You can walk 'cd..' / 'cd foldername' to the file, but it's better to add a path for the file's folder to your 'user environment variables'.  You can easily find better explanation on internet, but you can also keep reading. In windows 7, go to control panel, user accounts, (left side menu) change variables of my environment (or something like that). Probably theres alrdy a PATH variable with some value. If not, create it. So you edit it, add a comma in the end of existing value and enter a new path to the folder (not file) where psql.exe rests peacefully. In windows 10 (and probably win7 too actually) you may press window-key and search for system environment variables. There you don't need to add comma+newpath, you can just add a new entry.


After this you will be able to enter psql anywhere.

topLevelComment.author: Thoerni
topLevelComment.text:
To anyone getting an error when using the psql command in Windows Terminal: 
You need to add "psql" to your system path variables:

- In the search bar, type "env" and click on "Edit the system environment variables"
- Click on "Environment Variables"
- Then, in the "System Variables" table, click on the column with the Variable name "Path" and then click on "Edit"
- Click on "New" and paste the path to the "bin" folder of your psql installation. E.g. in my case, its "C:\Program Files\PostgreSQL\13\bin", but it could be different based on where you installed PostgreSQL or what version you have.

Now restart the Console, and the command should work.

topLevelComment.author: Ugljesa Vojvodic
topLevelComment.text:
For Windows users it's even easier, even though it seems to be confusing, just enter database name when it ask for it. 
This how it looks in the shell:
-
Server [localhost]:
Database [postgres]: test
Port [5433]:
Username [postgres]:
Password for user postgres:your_pw
-
Please note when you connect for the first time you are actually connect to default one and that's why you don't enter any name, it will have name"postgres", and the owner is also default one, guess the name - "postgres".
-
When you login with all empty parameters you noted line in terminal like "postgres=#", well the part before "=#" is actually name of database, so in this default case "postgres".
-
You noted he has owner "amigoscode" (when he list all databases) , it's actually added role, check postgres documentation how to add role and change owner of table.
-
Also, when you are in "postgres=#" database you can easily switch to another (that is already created, it won't create it by itself) database using command: 
\c another_database_name 
(example: "postgres=# \c test"
 result: "test=#")

topLevelComment.author: James Jensen
topLevelComment.text:
Watching this to catch up on PostgreSQL. Excellent presentation format.

One microscopic nitpick at 7:44 — the term "relational" in relational database doesn't refer to relations between tables, despite that being the obvious meaning. It refers to it being based on the relational algebra, which is so named because it involves operations on "relations," which are roughly the same thing as SQL's tables.

Nobody actually needs to know any of this. I'm just being pedantic.

@blazefirer ​ The comments section has some examples. -h localhost -p... nope. psql --help... nope (worked in regular windows command prompt, git bash...), and more. At this point I am just Googling for alternative ways to enter things or skipping the step if it's not essential, e.g. the \i step which didn't work starting from Users... need to start from C:/... and the part where he was checking where the file was sitting with cd etc, just skipped it because it wasn't working. while installing it gives an error saying: "Unable to write in TEMP environment variable path" 
PLEASE HELP!

replies.author: Ajene Grant
replies.text: Nandini Goyal type into your windows search bar (bottom left) “system”. Click on the one with “control panel” in the name (or just click control panel if it pops up as an app). Once in there, hit “Advanced system settings”. It will be the last option at the upper left hand list of items. A window will pop up, click on “Environment Variables...”. The first box of items will have an option called “Path”. Click on it and press edit. Now you are in your PATH and can add what you need. I hope this helps, I know windows can be fickle in how to access things from machine to machine
